facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1658 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1658 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 213 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order. dated November 19, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 213 of 1964. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: N. Sinha and B.P. Jha, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J. This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court dismissing a petition filed under s. 33

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed a petition filed under s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court dismissing a petition filed under s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Contract entered into between appellant and the respondent on January 28, 1964 for sale of 200 bags of Cone yarn

anchor.surface_text: A companytract was entered into between appellant and the respondent on January 28, 1964 for sale of 200 bags of Cone yarn. The companytract inter alia companytained the following terms and companyditions

facts.text: Contract provided that in case of any dispute arising out of this contract the matter in dispute shall be referred to the arbitration of the Indian Chamber of Commerce whose decision shall be binding on both the parties

anchor.surface_text: In case of any dispute arising out of this companytract the matter in dispute shall be referred to the arbitration of the Indian Chamber of Commerce whose decision shall be binding on both the parties. The Court at Calcutta alone and numberother companyrt whatsoever shall have jurisdiction

facts.text: Court at Calcutta alone shall have jurisdiction to entertain and try suits in respect of any claim or disputes arising out of or under this contract

anchor.surface_text: The Court at Calcutta alone and numberother companyrt whatsoever shall have jurisdiction to entertain and try suits in respect of any claim or disputes arising out of or under this companytract or in any way relating to the same.

facts.text: Certain disputes arose between the parties relating to the supply of goods

anchor.surface_text: Certain disputes arose between the parties relating to the supply of goods and the respondent demanded a payment of Rs. 25,658.90 as price of the goods alleged to have been supplied.

facts.text: Respondent demanded a payment of Rs. 25,658.90 as price of the goods alleged to have been supplied

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent demanded a payment of Rs. 25,658.90 as price of the goods alleged to have been supplied. The appellant maintained that the said goods were number according to the companytract and had been rightly rejected.

facts.text: Appellant maintained that the said goods were not according to the contract and had been rightly rejected

anchor.surface_text: The appellant maintained that the said goods were number according to the companytract and had been rightly rejected. The appellant did number happen to be a member of the Indian Chamber of Commerce, Calcutta, whereas the respondent was a member.

facts.text: Appellant did not happen to be a member of the Indian Chamber of Commerce, Calcutta, whereas the respondent was a member

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number happen to be a member of the Indian Chamber of Commerce, Calcutta, whereas the respondent was a member. The dispute having been referred to the Chamber the appellant wrote to the Registrar of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce

facts.text: Dispute having been referred to the Chamber

anchor.surface_text: The dispute having been referred to the Chamber the appellant wrote to the Registrar of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce to intimate the names of the persons companystituting the companyrt

facts.text: Appellant wrote to the Registrar of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce to intimate the names of the persons constituting the court

anchor.surface_text: the appellant wrote to the Registrar of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Chamber of Commerce to intimate the names of the persons companystituting the companyrt to enable the appellant to ascertain whether they were independent and disinterested persons.

facts.text: Registrar sent a reply saying that the names of the arbitrators constituting the court could not be disclosed to the appellant as it was a nonmember

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar sent a reply saying that the names of the arbitrators companystituting the companyrt companyld number be disclosed to the appellant as it was a numbermember. Later on a list of the office-bearers and companymittee members was sent

facts.text: Later on a list of the office-bearers and committee members was sent but according to the appellant the names of the arbitrators were not disclosed

anchor.surface_text: Later on a list of the office-bearers and companymittee members was sent but according to the appellant the names of the arbitrators were number disclosed. In September 1964 the Registrar intimated that the meeting of the companyrt of the arbitrators would be held

facts.text: In September 1964 the Registrar intimated that the meeting of the court of the arbitrators would be held on September 24, 1964

anchor.surface_text: In September 1964 the Registrar intimated that the meeting of the companyrt of the arbitrators would be held on September 24, 1964. There was further companyrespondence The appellants. attorney again sought information

facts.text: Appellant's attorney again sought information regarding the names and particulars of the arbitrators but without success

anchor.surface_text: There was further companyrespondence The appellants. attorney again sought information regarding the names and particulars of the arbitrators but without success. Ultimately the appellant filed an application under s. 33 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed an application under s. 33 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the appellant filed an application under s. 33 of the Act. The case of the appellant was that the arbitration agreement companytained in the companytract was void and ineffective

facts.text: Appellant's case was that the arbitration agreement contained in the contract was void and ineffective as clauses a and b reproduced above were in conflict with each other and that the Rules of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Indian Chamber of Commerce were illegal and void

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that the arbitration agreement companytained in the companytract was void and ineffective as clauses  a  and  b  reproduced above were in companyflict with each other and that the Rules of the Tribunal of Arbitration of the Indian Chamber of Commerce were illegal and void.

facts.text: High Court repelled all the contentions raised before it and dismissed the application

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled all the companytentions raised before it and dismissed the application. The main emphasis before us has been laid by learned companynsel for the appellant on R. III of the Rules

facts.text: Reliance placed before High Court and Supreme Court on unreported judgment of Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 95 of 1963 Suraj Ratan Binany v. Hindustan Motors Ltd. decided on C-4-1964

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court and before us reliance has been placed on an unreported judgment of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 95 of 1963  Suraj Ratan Binany v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.  1 . In that Decided on C--4-964.

facts.text: In that case a similar contention had been raised and it was held that if the names of the arbitrators were not known to the parties until the award was filed the parties would not be in a position to know whether the arbitrators had misconducted themselves

anchor.surface_text: In that Decided on C--4-964. case a similar companytention had been raised and it was held that if the names of the arbitrators were number known to the parties until the award was filed the parties would number be in a position to know whether the arbitrators had misconducted themselves entailing removal under s. 11

facts.text: Judgment under appeal did not follow the view in Matter No. 95 of 1963 and held that the Arbitration Rules of the Chamber of Commerce did not offend any sections of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In the judgment under appeal, however, that view was number followed and it has been held that the Arbitration Rules of the Chamber of Commerce did number offend any of the sections of the Act as the powers of the companyrt under ss. 5 and 11 remained unaffected

facts.text: Supreme Court holds there is no merit in the challenge to the validity of the arbitration agreement on the ground that the Rules enable the Registrar to withhold disclosure of names to non-member

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment there is numbermerit in the challenge to the validity of the arbitration agreement on the ground that the Rules of the Indian Chamber of Commerce which is to be the arbitrator, enable the Registrar of that Chamber to withhold disclosure of the names of the Arbitration Court to a party which does number

facts.text: Appeal fails and it is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and it is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 19, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Matter No. 213 of 1964.
This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court dismissing a petition filed under s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act, hereinafter called the Act.
s. 33 of the Indian Arbitration Act, hereinafter called the Act. A contract was entered into between appellant and the respondent on January 28, 1964 for sale of 200 bags of Cone yarn.

anchor.surface_text: We can see no conflict between Rule III  3   of the Rules of Arbitration of Chamber of Commerce and ss. 5 and 11 or s. 30 of the Act. These Rules do not interfere with or take away the powers and the jurisdiction of the court under the aforesaid provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been drawn to a statement in Russell on Arbitration, 17th Edn., at page 207 that the appointment of an arbitrator by a party is not complete without communication thereof to the other party.

holdings.text: there is no merit in the challenge to the validity of the arbitration agreement on the ground that the Rules of the Indian Chamber of Commerce which is to be the arbitrator, enable the Registrar of that Chamber to withhold disclosure of the names of the Arbitration Court to a party which does not happen to be a member of the Chamber

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment there is no merit in the challenge to the validity of the arbitration agreement on the ground that the Rules of the Indian Chamber of Commerce which is to be the arbitrator, enable the Registrar of that Chamber to withhold disclosure of the names of the Arbitration Court to a party which does not happen to be a member of the Chamber. The power given to the Registrar is discretionary and he is not bound in every case to refuse to disclose the names.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Registrar's power discretionary; names disclosed upon commencement of proceedings allowing objections; court powers under ss 5 and 11 unaffected

holdings.text: The power given to the Registrar is discretionary and he is not bound in every case to refuse to disclose the names

anchor.surface_text: The power given to the Registrar is discretionary and he is not bound in every case to refuse to disclose the names. At any rate, as soon as proceedings before the arbitrators commence both parties are in a position to know the names and particulars of the arbitrators and if there is any objection on well known grounds to their conducting the arbitration the same can be taken at that stage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary authority under Rule III(3); disclosure not mandatory prior to proceedings

holdings.text: as soon as proceedings before the arbitrators commence both parties are in a position to know the names and particulars of the arbitrators and if there is any objection on well known grounds to their conducting the arbitration the same can be taken at that stage

anchor.surface_text: At any rate, as soon as proceedings before the arbitrators commence both parties are in a position to know the names and particulars of the arbitrators and if there is any objection on well known grounds to their conducting the arbitration the same can be taken at that stage. Under s. 5 it is not essential that the authority of an appointed arbitrator should be got revoked before the commencement of the arbitration proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objections possible at start of proceedings; no prejudice from prior non-disclosure

holdings.text: Under s. 5 it is not essential that the authority of an appointed arbitrator should be got revoked before the commencement of the arbitration proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 5 it is not essential that the authority of an appointed arbitrator should be got revoked before the commencement of the arbitration proceedings. Section 11 contemplates a stage subsequent to the arbitrators entering on the reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 revocation not required pre-commencement; applies to appointed arbitrators

holdings.text: Section 11 contemplates a stage subsequent to the arbitrators entering on the reference

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 contemplates a stage subsequent to the arbitrators entering on the reference. We can see no conflict between Rule III ( 3 ) of the Rules of Arbitration of Chamber of Commerce and ss. 5 and 11 or s. 30 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconduct grounds arise post-entry into reference

holdings.text: We can see no conflict between Rule III ( 3 ) of the Rules of Arbitration of Chamber of Commerce and ss. 5 and 11 or s. 30 of the Act. These Rules do not interfere with or take away the powers and the jurisdiction of the court under the aforesaid provisions

anchor.surface_text: We can see no conflict between Rule III ( 3 ) of the Rules of Arbitration of Chamber of Commerce and ss. 5 and 11 or s. 30 of the Act. These Rules do not interfere with or take away the powers and the jurisdiction of the court under the aforesaid provisions. It must be remembered that the appellant agreed to submit to the arbitration of Indian Chamber of Commerce which meant that it was bound by all the Rules of Arbitration of the said body.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chamber rules preserve court jurisdiction under ss 5,11,30

holdings.text: the appellant agreed to submit to the arbitration of Indian Chamber of Commerce which meant that it was bound by all the Rules of Arbitration of the said body. No illegality or invalidity can be projected into the agreement by the presence of Rule III (3)

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the appellant agreed to submit to the arbitration of Indian Chamber of Commerce which meant that it was bound by all the Rules of Arbitration of the said body. No illegality or invalidity can be projected into the agreement by the presence of Rule III (3). Our attention has been drawn to a statement in Russell on Arbitration, 17th Edn., at page 207 that the appointment of an arbitrator by a party is not complete without communication thereof to the other party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement incorporates all chamber rules; Rule III(3) does not invalidate

holdings.text: the appointment of an arbitrator by a party is not complete without communication thereof to the other party [distinguished]; the appointment of the arbitrator was thus complete in every sense in the present case. It could not be said that it would become complete only when the names of persons constituting the court of arbitration were communicated

anchor.surface_text: This Rule can be of no avail to the appellant because in the present case the arbitrator was known, the arbitrator being the Chamber of Commerce. Under its Rules the Chamber is authorised to delegate its power to a smaller body. As the Rules were expressly or by necessary implication incorporated into the contract the Chamber would have the power to appoint a court, by its Registrar, to decide the dispute. The appointment of the arbitrator was thus complete in every sense in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chamber as arbitrator known; delegation under rules valid; names communication not required for completion

holdings.text: The appeal fails and it is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and it is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected upholding High Court dismissal of s.33 petition

holdings.text: the Rules of Chamber of Commerce in various parts of the country contain provisions similar to the one the validity of which has been impugned. For instance Rule V (4) of the Rules of Bengal Chamber of Commerce provides that the names or name of the persons or person constituting the court shall not ordinarily be disclosed to the parties nor shall the parties be entitled to such information as of right. A similar rule is to be found in bye-law 8 of the Bombay Chamber of Commerce and Rule V (5) of Arbitration Rules of Madras Chamber of Commerce

anchor.surface_text: It is noteworthy that the Rules of Chamber of Commerce in various parts of the country contain provisions similar to the one the validity of which has been impugned. For instance Rule V (4) of the Rules of Bengal Chamber of Commerce provides that the names or name of the persons or person constituting the court shall not ordinarily be disclosed to the parties nor shall the parties be entitled to such information as of right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevalent practice in other chambers supports validity

holdings.text: the aforesaid Rule which has been framed by all these bodies of long standing and experience in the field of business is based on the elimination of all possibility or chance of a party trying to influence the members of the Arbitration Court before they enter upon or proceed with the reference

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the aforesaid Rule which has been framed by all these bodies of long standing and experience in the field of business is based on the elimination of all possibility or chance of a party trying to influence the members of the Arbitration Court before they enter upon or proceed with the reference.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment there is no merit in the challenge to the validity of the arbitration agreement on the ground that the Rules of the Indian Chamber of Commerce which is to be the arbitrator, enable the Registrar of that Chamber to withhold disclosure of the names of the Arbitration Court to a party which does not happen to be a member of the Chamber. The power given to the Registrar is discretionary and he is not bound in every case to refuse to disclose the names.
The appeal fails and it is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on discretionary nature of Registrar's power supports concept c5 that natural justice is not violated by non-disclosure of names prior to proceedings.
Holding h2 on discretionary non-disclosure supports c6 that Rule III discretionary non-disclosure does not conflict
Holding h2 that Registrar's power to disclose names is discretionary addresses issue i3 by providing basis why non-disclosure does not necessarily violate natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The power given to the Registrar is discretionary and he is not bound in every case to refuse to disclose the names. At any rate, as soon as proceedings before the arbitrators commence both parties are in a position to know the names and particulars of the arbitrators and if there is any objection on well known grounds to their conducting the arbitration the same can be taken at that stage.
The appeal fails and it is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: At any rate, as soon as proceedings before the arbitrators commence both parties are in a position to know the names and particulars of the arbitrators and if there is any objection on well known grounds to their conducting the arbitration the same can be taken at that stage. Under s. 5 it is not essential that the authority of an appointed arbitrator should be got revoked before the commencement of the arbitration proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We can see no conflict between Rule III ( 3 ) of the Rules of Arbitration of Chamber of Commerce and ss. 5 and 11 or s. 30 of the Act. These Rules do not interfere with or take away the powers and the jurisdiction of the court under the aforesaid provisions. It must be remembered that the appellant agreed to submit to the arbitration of Indian Chamber of Commerce which meant that it was bound by all the Rules of Arbitration of the said body.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the appellant agreed to submit to the arbitration of Indian Chamber of Commerce which meant that it was bound by all the Rules of Arbitration of the said body. No illegality or invalidity can be projected into the agreement by the presence of Rule III (3). Our attention has been drawn to a statement in Russell on Arbitration, 17th Edn., at page 207 that the appointment of an arbitrator by a party is not complete without communication thereof to the other party.
The appeal fails and it is dismissed.
11 or s. 30 of the Act. These Rules do number interfere with or take away the powers and the jurisdiction of the companyrt under the aforesaid provis

edges.explanation: Holding h8 appointment complete addresses i6

anchor.surface_text: This Rule can be of no avail to the appellant because in the present case the arbitrator was known, the arbitrator being the Chamber of Commerce. Under its Rules the Chamber is authorised to delegate its power to a smaller body. As the Rules were expressly or by necessary implication incorporated into the contract the Chamber would have the power to appoint a court, by its Registrar, to decide the dispute. The appointment of the arbitrator was thus complete in every sense in the present case.
The appeal fails and it is dismissed.
